Exact unconditional sampling from max-stable random vectors

LÃ©o Belzile, HEC MontrÃ©al

2025-09-30

Source: vignettes/mev-vignette.Rmd
mev-vignette.Rmd

The mev package was originally introduced to implement the exact unconditional sampling algorithms in Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting (2016). The two algorithms therein allow one to simulate simple max-stable random vectors. The implementation will work efficiently for moderate dimensions.

Functions and use

There are two main functions, rmev and rmevspec. rmev samples from simple max-stable processes, meaning it will return an nÃ—dn \times d matrix of samples, where each of the column has a sample from a unit Frechet distribution. In constrast, rmevspec returns sample on the unit simplex from the spectral (or angular) measure. One could use this to test estimation based on spectral densities, or to construct samples from Pareto processes.

The syntax is

library(mev)
#Sample of size 1000 from a 5-dimensional logistic model
x <- rmev(n=1000, d=5, param=0.5, model="log")
#Marginal parameters are all standard Frechet, meaning GEV(1,1,1)
apply(x, 2, function(col){ismev::gev.fit(col, show=FALSE)$mle})
##           [,1]      [,2]      [,3]      [,4]      [,5]
## [1,] 0.9704836 0.9680742 0.9762923 0.9690277 0.9513841
## [2,] 0.9224421 0.9131969 0.9363205 0.9671969 0.8878784
## [3,] 0.9445221 0.9560178 0.9544973 0.9884361 0.9390865
#Sample from the corresponding spectral density
w <- rmevspec(n=1000, d=5, param=0.5, model="log")
#All rows sum to 1 by construction
head(rowSums(w))
## [1] 1 1 1 1 1 1
#The marginal mean is 1/d
round(colMeans(w),2)
## [1] 0.20 0.21 0.19 0.20 0.20

Description of the models implemented

The different models implemented are described in Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting (2016), but some other models can be found and are described here. Throughout, we consider dd-variate models and let ğ”¹d\mathbb{B}_d be the collection of all nonempty subsets of {1,â€¦,d}\{1, \ldots, d\}.

Logistic

The logistic model (log) of Gumbel (1960) has distribution function Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’(âˆ‘i=1nxiâˆ’Î±)1Î±]\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \leq \boldsymbol{x})= \exp \left[ - \left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} {x_i}^{-\alpha}\right)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\right] \end{align*} for Î±>1\alpha>1. The spectral measure density is hğ–(ğ°)=1dÎ“(dâˆ’Î±)Î“(1âˆ’Î±)Î±dâˆ’1(âˆj=1dwj)âˆ’(Î±+1)(âˆ‘j=1dwjâˆ’Î±)1/Î±âˆ’d,ğ°âˆˆğ•Šd\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w})=\frac{1}{d}\frac{\Gamma(d-\alpha)}{\Gamma(1-\alpha)}\alpha^{d-1}\left( \prod_{j=1}^d w_j\right)^{-(\alpha+1)}\left(\sum_{j=1}^d w_j^{-\alpha}\right)^{1/\alpha-d}, \qquad \boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}_d \end{align*}

Asymmetric logistic distribution

The alog model was proposed by Tawn (1990). It shares the same parametrization as the evd package, merely replacing the algorithm for the generation of logistic variates. The distribution function of the dd-variate asymmetric logistic distribution is Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’âˆ‘bâˆˆğ”¹d(âˆ‘iâˆˆb(Î¸i,bxi)Î±b)1Î±b],\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \le \boldsymbol{x}) = \exp \left[ -\sum_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d}\left(\sum_{i \in b} \left(\frac{\theta_{i, b}}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_b}\right)^{\frac{1}{\alpha_b}}\right], \end{align*}

The parameters Î¸i,b\theta_{i, b} must be provided in a list and represent the asymmetry parameter. The sampling algorithm, from Stephenson (2003) gives some insight on the construction mechanism as a max-mixture of logistic distributions. Consider sampling ğ™b\boldsymbol{Z}_b from a logistic distribution of dimension |b||b| (or FrÃ©chet variates if |b|=1)|b|=1) with parameter Î±b\alpha_b (possibly recycled). Each marginal value corresponds to the maximum of the weighted corresponding entry. That is, Xi=maxbâˆˆğ”¹dÎ¸i,bZi,bX_{i}=\max_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d}\theta_{i, b}Z_{i,b} for all i=1,â€¦,di=1, \ldots, d. The max-mixture is valid provided that âˆ‘bâˆˆğ”¹dÎ¸i,b=1\sum_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d} \theta_{i,b}=1 for i=1,â€¦,d.i=1, \ldots, d. As such, empirical estimates of the spectral measure will almost surely place mass on the inside of the simplex rather than on subfaces.

Negative logistic distribution

The neglog distribution function due to Galambos (1975) is Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’âˆ‘bâˆˆğ”¹d(âˆ’1)|b|(âˆ‘iâˆˆbxiÎ±)âˆ’1Î±]\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \le \boldsymbol{x}) = \exp \left[ -\sum_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d} (-1)^{|b|}\left(\sum_{i \in b} {x_i}^{\alpha}\right)^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\right] \end{align*} for Î±â‰¥0\alpha \geq 0(Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting 2016). The associated spectral density is hğ–(ğ°)=1dÎ“(1/Î±+1)Î“(1/Î±+dâˆ’1)Î±d(âˆi=1dwj)Î±âˆ’1(âˆ‘i=1dwiÎ±)âˆ’1/Î±âˆ’d\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w}) = \frac{1}{d} \frac{\Gamma(1/\alpha+1)}{\Gamma(1/\alpha + d-1)} \alpha^d\left(\prod_{i=1}^d w_j\right)^{\alpha-1}\left(\sum_{i=1}^d w_i^{\alpha}\right)^{-1/\alpha-d} \end{align*}

Asymmetric negative logistic distribution

The asymmetric negative logistic (aneglog) model is alluded to in Joe (1990) as a generalization of the Galambos model. It is constructed in the same way as the asymmetric logistic distribution; see Theorem~1 in Stephenson (2003). Let Î±bâ‰¤0\alpha_b \leq 0 for all bâˆˆğ”¹db \in \mathbb{B}_d and Î¸i,bâ‰¥0\theta_{i, b} \geq 0 with âˆ‘bâˆˆğ”¹dÎ¸i,b=1\sum_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d} \theta_{i, b} =1 for i=1,â€¦,di=1, \ldots, d; the distribution function is Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’âˆ‘bâˆˆğ”¹d(âˆ’1)|b|{âˆ‘iâˆˆb(Î¸i,bxi)Î±b}1Î±b].\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \le \boldsymbol{x}) = \exp \left[ -\sum_{b \in \mathbb{B}_d}(-1)^{|b|} \left\{\sum_{i \in b} \left(\frac{\theta_{i, b}}{x_i}\right)^{\alpha_b}\right\}^{\frac{1}{\alpha_b}}\right]. \end{align*} In particular, it does not correspond to the ``negative logistic distributionâ€™â€™ given in e.g., Section 4.2 of Coles and Tawn (1991) or Section3.5.3 of Kotz and Nadarajah (2000). The latter is not a valid distribution function in dimension dâ‰¥3d \geq 3 as the constraints therein on the parameters Î¸i,b\theta_{i, b} are necessary, but not sufficient.

Joe (1990) mentions generalizations of the distribution as given above but the constraints were not enforced elsewhere in the literature. The proof that the distribution is valid follows from Theorem~1 of Stephenson (2003) as it is a max-mixture. Note that the parametrization of the asymmetric negative logistic distribution does not match the bivariate implementation of rbvevd.

Multilogistic distribution

This multivariate extension of the logistic, termed multilogistic (bilog) proposed by M.-O. Boldi (2009), places mass on the interior of the simplex. Let ğ–âˆˆğ•Šd\boldsymbol{W} \in \mathbb{S}_d be the solution of WjWd=CjUjâˆ’Î±jCdUdâˆ’Î±d,j=1,â€¦,d\begin{align*} \frac{W_j}{W_d}=\frac{C_jU_j^{-\alpha_j}}{C_dU_d^{-\alpha_d}}, \quad j=1, \ldots, d \end{align*} where Cj=Î“(dâˆ’Î±j)/Î“(1âˆ’Î±j)C_j=\Gamma(d-\alpha_j)/\Gamma(1-\alpha_j) for j=1,â€¦,dj=1, \ldots, d and ğ”âˆˆğ•Šd\boldsymbol{U} \in \mathbb{S}_d follows a dd-mixture of Dirichlet with the jjth component being ğ’Ÿ(ğŸâˆ’Î´jÎ±j)\mathcal{D}(\boldsymbol{1}-\delta_{j}\alpha_j), so that the mixture has density function hğ”(ğ®)=1dâˆ‘j=1dÎ“(dâˆ’Î±j)Î“(1âˆ’Î±j)ujâˆ’Î±j\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{U}}(\boldsymbol{u})=\frac{1}{d} \sum_{j=1}^d \frac{\Gamma(d-\alpha_j)}{\Gamma(1-\alpha_j)} u_j^{-\alpha_j} \end{align*} for 0<Î±j<1,j=1,â€¦,d0<\alpha_j <1, j=1, \ldots, d. The spectral density of the multilogistic distribution is thus hğ–(ğ°)=1d(âˆ‘j=1dÎ±juj)âˆ’1(âˆj=1dÎ±jud)(âˆ‘j=1dÎ“(dâˆ’Î±j)Î“(1âˆ’Î±j)ujâˆ’Î±j)âˆj=1dwjâˆ’1\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w}) = \frac{1}{d} \left(\sum_{j=1}^d \alpha_ju_j\right)^{-1} \left(\prod_{j=1}^d \alpha_ju_d \right)\left(\sum_{j=1}^d \frac{\Gamma(d-\alpha_j)}{\Gamma(1-\alpha_j)}u_j^{-\alpha_j}\right)\prod_{j=1}^d w_j^{-1} \end{align*} for Î±jâˆˆ(0,1)\alpha_j \in (0,1)(j=1,â€¦,d)(j=1, \ldots, d).

Coles and Tawn Dirichlet distribution

The Dirichlet (ct) model of Coles and Tawn (1991) has spectral density hğ–(ğ°)=1dÎ“(1+âˆ‘j=1dÎ±j)âˆj=1dÎ±jwj(âˆ‘j=1dÎ±jwj)âˆ’(d+1)âˆj=1dÎ±jâˆj=1d(Î±jwjâˆ‘k=1dÎ±kwk)Î±jâˆ’1\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w}) = \frac{1}{d} \frac{\Gamma \left(1+\sum_{j=1}^d \alpha_j\right)}{\prod_{j=1}^d \alpha_jw_j} \left(\sum_{j=1}^d \alpha_jw_j\right)^{-(d+1)}\prod_{j=1}^d \alpha_j \prod_{j=1}^d \left(\frac{\alpha_jw_j}{\sum_{k=1}^d \alpha_kw_k}\right)^{\alpha_j-1} \end{align*} for Î±j>0.\alpha_j>0.

Scaled extremal Dirichlet

The angular density of the scaled extremal Dirichlet (sdir) model with parameters Ï>âˆ’min(ğ›‚)\rho > -\min(\boldsymbol{\alpha}) and ğ›‚âˆˆâ„+d\boldsymbol{\alpha} \in \mathbb{R}^{d}_{+} is given, for all ğ°âˆˆğ•Šd\boldsymbol{w} \in \mathbb{S}_d, by hğ–(ğ°)=Î“(Î±â€¾+Ï)dÏdâˆ’1âˆi=1dÎ“(Î±i)âŸ¨{ğœ(ğ›‚,Ï)}1/Ï,ğ°1/ÏâŸ©âˆ’Ïâˆ’Î±â€¾âˆi=1d{c(Î±i,Ï)}Î±i/ÏwiÎ±i/Ïâˆ’1.\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w})=\frac{\Gamma(\bar{\alpha}+\rho)}{d\rho^{d-1}\prod_{i=1}^d\Gamma(\alpha_i)} \bigl\langle\{\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\rho)\}^{1/\rho},\boldsymbol{w}^{1/\rho}\bigr\rangle^{-\rho-\bar{\alpha}}\prod_{i=1}^{d} \{c(\alpha_i,\rho)\}^{\alpha_i/\rho}w_i^{\alpha_i/\rho-1}. \end{align*} where ğœ(ğ›‚,Ï)\boldsymbol{c}(\boldsymbol{\alpha},\rho) is the dd-vector with entries Î“(Î±i+Ï)/Î“(Î±i)\Gamma(\alpha_i+\rho)/\Gamma(\alpha_i) for i=1,â€¦,di=1, \ldots, d and âŸ¨â‹…,â‹…âŸ©\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle denotes the inner product between two vectors.

Hueslerâ€“Reiss

The Hueslerâ€“Reiss model (hr), due to HÃ¼sler and Reiss (1989), is a special case of the Brownâ€“Resnick process. While Engelke et al. (2015) state that H"uslerâ€“Reiss variates can be sampled following the same scheme, the spatial analog is conditioned on a particular site (ğ¬0\boldsymbol{s}_0), which complicates the comparisons with the other methods.

Let Iâˆ’j={1,â€¦,d}\{j}I_{-j}=\{1, \ldots, d\} \setminus \{j\} and Î»ij2â‰¥0\lambda_{ij}^2 \geq 0 be entries of a strictly conditionally negative definite matrix ğš²\boldsymbol{\Lambda}, for which Î»ij2=Î»ji2\lambda_{ij}^2=\lambda_{ji}^2. Then, following Nikoloulopoulos, Joe, and Li (2009) (Remark~2.5) and Huser and Davison (2013), we can write the distribution function as Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’âˆ‘j=1d1xjÎ¦dâˆ’1,ğšºâˆ’j(Î»ijâˆ’12Î»ijlog(xjxi),iâˆˆIâˆ’j)].\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \le \boldsymbol{x}) = \exp \left[ -\sum_{j=1}^d \frac{1}{x_j} \Phi_{d-1, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{-j}} \left( \lambda_{ij}- \frac{1}{2\lambda_{ij}} \log\left(\frac{x_j}{x_i}\right), i \in I_{-j}\right)\right]. \end{align*} where the partial correlation matrix ğšºâˆ’j\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{-j} has elements ğœši,k;j=Î»ij2+Î»kj2âˆ’Î»ik22Î»ijÎ»kj\begin{align*} \varrho_{i,k; j}= \frac{\lambda_{ij}^2+\lambda_{kj}^2-\lambda_{ik}^2}{2\lambda_{ij}\lambda_{kj}} \end{align*} and Î»ii=0\lambda_{ii}=0 for all iâˆˆIâˆ’ji \in I_{-j} so that the diagonal entries ğœši,i;j=1\varrho_{i,i; j}=1. Engelke et al. (2015) uses the covariance matrix with entries are ğœ=2(Î»ij2+Î»kj2âˆ’Î»ik2)\varsigma=2(\lambda_{ij}^2+\lambda_{kj}^2-\lambda_{ik}^2), so the resulting expression is evaluated at 2ğ›Œ.j2âˆ’log(xj/ğ±âˆ’j)2\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{.j}^2-\log({x_j}/{\boldsymbol{x}_{-j}}) instead. We recover the same expression by standardizing, since this amounts to division by the standard deviations 2ğ›Œ.j2\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{.j}

The package implementation has a bivariate implementation of the H"uslerâ€“Reiss distribution with dependence parameter rr, with rik=1/Î»ikr_{ik}=1/\lambda_{ik} or 2/r=2Î³(ğ¡)2/r=\sqrt{2\gamma(\boldsymbol{h})} for ğ¡=âˆ¥ğ¬iâˆ’ğ¬iâˆ¥\boldsymbol{h}=\|\boldsymbol{s}_i-\boldsymbol{s}_i\| for the Brownâ€“Resnick model. In this setting, it is particularly easy since the only requirement is non-negativity of the parameter. For inference in dimension d>2d>2, one needs to impose the constraint ğš²={Î»ij2}i,j=1dâˆˆğ’Ÿ\boldsymbol{\Lambda}=\{\lambda_{ij}^2\}_{i, j=1}^d \in \mathcal{D} (cf. Engelke et al. (2015), p.3), where ğ’Ÿ={ğ€âˆˆ[0,âˆ)dÃ—d:ğ±âŠ¤ğ€ğ±<0,âˆ€ğ±âˆˆâ„d\{ğŸ} with âˆ‘i=1dxi=0,aij=aji,aii=0âˆ€i,jâˆˆ{1,â€¦,d}}\begin{multline*} \mathcal{D}=\Biggl\{\mathbf{A}\in [0, \infty)^{d\times d}: \boldsymbol{x}^\top\!\!\mathbf{A}\boldsymbol{x} <0, \ \forall \ \boldsymbol{x} \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \setminus\{\boldsymbol{0}\} \\ \qquad \text{ with } \sum_{i=1}^d x_i=0, a_{ij}=a_{ji}, a_{ii}=0 \ \forall \ i, j \in \{1,\ldots, d\}\Biggr\} \end{multline*} denotes the set of symmetric conditionally negative definite matrices with zero diagonal entries. An avenue to automatically satisfy these requirements is to optimize over a symmetric positive definite matrix parameter ğ›´=ğ‹âŠ¤ğ‹\boldsymbol{\varSigma}=\mathbf{L}^\top\mathbf{L}, where ğ‹\mathbf{L} is an upper triangular matrix whose diagonal element are on the log-scale to ensure uniqueness of the Cholesky factorization; see Pinheiro and Bates (1996). By taking ğš²(ğ›´)=(0diag(ğ›´)âŠ¤diag(ğ›´)ğŸdiag(ğ›´)âŠ¤+diag(ğ›´)ğŸâŠ¤âˆ’2ğ›´)\begin{align*} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}(\boldsymbol{\varSigma})= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & \mathrm{diag} (\boldsymbol{\varSigma})^\top \\ \mathrm{diag}(\boldsymbol{\varSigma}) & \boldsymbol{1}\mathrm{diag}(\boldsymbol{\varSigma})^\top + \mathrm{diag}(\boldsymbol{\varSigma})\boldsymbol{1}^\top - 2 \boldsymbol{\varSigma} \end{pmatrix} \end{align*} one can perform unconstrained optimization for the non-zero elements of ğ‹\mathbf{L} which are in one-to-one correspondence with those of ğš²\boldsymbol{\Lambda}.

It easily follows that generating ğ™\boldsymbol{Z} from a dâˆ’1d-1 dimensional log-Gaussian distribution with covariance ğ–¢ğ—ˆ(Zi,Zk)=2(Î»ij2+Î»kj2âˆ’Î»ik2)\mathsf{Co}(Z_i, Z_k)=2(\lambda_{ij}^2+\lambda_{kj}^2-\lambda_{ik}^2) for i,kâˆˆIâˆ’ji, k \in I_{-j} with mean vector âˆ’2Î»â€¢j2-2\lambda_{\bullet j}^2 gives the finite dimensional analog of the Brownâ€“Resnick process in the mixture representation of Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting (2016).

The function checks conditional negative definiteness of the matrix. The easiest way to do so negative definiteness of ğš²\boldsymbol{\Lambda} with real entries is to form ğš²Ìƒ=ğğš²ğâŠ¤\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}=\mathbf{P}\boldsymbol{\Lambda}\mathbf{P}^\top, where ğ\mathbf{P} is an dÃ—dd \times d matrix with ones on the diagonal, âˆ’1-1 on the (i,i+1)(i, i+1) entries for i=1,â€¦dâˆ’1i=1, \ldots d-1 and zeros elsewhere. If the matrix ğš²âˆˆğ’Ÿ\boldsymbol{\Lambda} \in \mathcal{D}, then the eigenvalues of the leading (dâˆ’1)Ã—(dâˆ’1)(d-1) \times (d-1) submatrix of ğš²Ìƒ\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}} will all be negative.

For a set of dd locations, one can supply the variogram matrix as valid input to the method.

Brownâ€“Resnick process

The Brownâ€“Resnick process (br) is the functional extension of the H"uslerâ€“Reiss distribution, and is a max-stable process associated with the log-Gaussian distribution. It is often in the spatial setting conditioned on a location (typically the origin). Users can provide a variogram function that takes distance as argument and is vectorized. If vario is provided, the model will simulate from an intrinsically stationary Gaussian process. The user can alternatively provide a covariance matrix sigma obtained by conditioning on a site, in which case simulations are from a stationary Gaussian process. See Engelke et al. (2015) or Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting (2016) for more information.

Extremal Student

The extremal Student (extstud) model of Nikoloulopoulos, Joe, and Li (2009), eq. 2.8, with unit FrÃ©chet margins is Pr(ğ—â‰¤ğ±)=exp[âˆ’âˆ‘j=1d1xjTdâˆ’1,Î½+1,ğ‘âˆ’j(Î½+11âˆ’Ïij2[(xixj)1/Î½âˆ’Ïij],iâˆˆIâˆ’j)],\begin{align*} \Pr(\boldsymbol{X} \le \boldsymbol{x}) = \exp \left[-\sum_{j=1}^d \frac{1}{x_j} T_{d-1, \nu+1, \mathbf{R}_{-j}}\left( \sqrt{\frac{\nu+1}{1-\rho_{ij}^2}} \left[\left(\frac{x_i}{x_j}\right)^{1/\nu}\!\!\!-\rho_{ij}\right], i \in I_{-j} \right)\right], \end{align*} where Tdâˆ’1T_{d-1} is the distribution function of the $d-1 $ dimensional Student-tt distribution and the partial correlation matrix ğ‘âˆ’j\mathbf{R}_{-j} has diagonal entry ri,i;j=1,ri,k;j=Ïikâˆ’ÏijÏkj1âˆ’Ïij21âˆ’Ïkj2r_{i,i;j}=1, \qquad r_{i,k;j}=\frac{\rho_{ik}-\rho_{ij}\rho_{kj}}{\sqrt{1-\rho_{ij}^2}\sqrt{1-\rho_{kj}^2}} for iâ‰ k,i,kâˆˆIâˆ’ji\neq k, i, k \in I_{-j}.

The user must provide a valid correlation matrix (the function checks for diagonal elements), which can be obtained from a variogram.

Dirichlet mixture

The Dirichlet mixture (dirmix) proposed by M.-O. Boldi and Davison (2007), see Dombry, Engelke, and Oesting (2016) for details on the mixture. The spectral density of the model is hğ–(ğ°)=âˆ‘k=1mÏ€kÎ“(Î±1k+â‹¯+Î±dk)âˆi=1dÎ“(Î±ik)(1âˆ’âˆ‘i=1dâˆ’1wi)Î±dkâˆ’1âˆi=1dâˆ’1wiÎ±ikâˆ’1\begin{align*} h_{\boldsymbol{W}}(\boldsymbol{w}) = \sum_{k=1}^m \pi_k \frac{\Gamma(\alpha_{1k}+ \cdots + \alpha_{dk})}{\prod_{i=1}^d \Gamma(\alpha_{ik})} \left(1-\sum_{i=1}^{d-1} w_i\right)^{\alpha_{dk}-1}\prod_{i=1}^{d-1} w_{i}^{\alpha_{ik}-1} \end{align*} The argument param is thus a dÃ—md \times m matrix of coefficients, while the argument for the mm-vector weights gives the relative contribution of each Dirichlet mixture component.

Smith model

The Smith model (smith) is from the unpublished report of Smith (1990). It corresponds to a moving maximum process on a domain ğ•\mathbb{X}. The de Haan representation of the process is Z(x)=maxiâˆˆâ„•Î¶ih(xâˆ’Î·i),Î·iâˆˆğ•\begin{align*} Z(x)=\max_{i \in \mathbb{N}} \zeta_i h(x-\eta_i), \qquad \eta_i \in \mathbb{X} \end{align*} where {Î¶i,Î·i}iâˆˆâ„•\{\zeta_i, \eta_i\}_{i \in \mathbb{N}} is a Poisson point process on â„+Ã—ğ•\mathbb{R}_{+} \times \mathbb{X} with intensity measure Î¶âˆ’2dÎ¶dÎ·\zeta^{-2}\mathrm{d} \zeta \mathrm{d} \eta and hh is the density of the multivariate Gaussian distribution. Other hh could be used in principle, but are not implemented.
